<@U0T37AGLS|balajipurusothaman> has joined the channel
<http://prnt.sc/afyr3o>
Any thoughts how to make gradient like that without killing the performance?
Considering that there could be a lot more points on graph
<http://prnt.sc/afyro0>
Here's the screenshot from current design with more points
And also the graph is real-time, updating every second
haven’t done any fancy drawings, but it seems to me that the gradient could be a background, and then you draw the white bit on top?
I generally avoid that stuff
There might be some gradient option when paint is set to fill, or if not you can set gradient to background and make the fill background white, and reverse the graph
But what should I fill at first? There's no any shape but line at this moment
Sorry, the line paint set to fill & stroke
maybe you could use parts of an image
kind of like a histogram
that way you don’t have to manually do the gradient
Why don’t just copy the `Path` used for drawing the line, and then extend it on both side to the bottom and draw it with a gradient-filled `Paint`?
histogram with bars of a width between two points?
something like that :confused:

> and then extend it on both side to the bottom
please explain this part
I’m just tossing ideas your way though…
<@U0R5K272T|marijnvdwerf> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/marijnvdwerf/F0T3DUC3Y/pasted_image_at_2016_03_16_02_41_pm.png|Pasted image at 2016-03-16, 2:41 PM>
You currently have a path like this
yep
Add one line at the start on the left, going straight down
and add one line at the right going straight down too
Now you have a shape you can fill
<@U0R5K272T|marijnvdwerf> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/marijnvdwerf/F0T3MM66B/pasted_image_at_2016_03_16_02_44_pm.png|Pasted image at 2016-03-16, 2:44 PM>

ah, now I got it. Yeah, building a shape like that was what I thought about, but that would damage the performance so hard. There are also features like scrolling and zooming on this chart and the number of points on single screen can reach up to 200
It’s probably fairly easy to give it a try, just to validate your suspicion
Are you possibly re-drawing this as fast as you can instead of once?
You could also probably optimise the entire thing by moving the canvas and only drawing the new data points.

Also, switching to a SurfaceView could help with performance, gives it it’s own thread and takes care of updating and stuff, at least I can handle 800 Rectangles updating constantly and still look pretty smooth (but keep writing and iteration/longer operations out of onDraw() ).

> You could also probably optimise the entire thing by moving the canvas and only drawing the new data points
yeah, good point
> switching to a SurfaceView
Is that assuming to use OpenGL?
I think it is still just a canvas, there is a OpenGL surfaceview too, but I dont mean that one
We use AndroidPlot library (don't ask me why =)), so there's not so much we can remake there
/gif fork it
extend everything
hack dex files
just do it
it works for facebook, and it’ll work for you
AST transform everything

Hi everyone. I was wondering how to go about capturing audio nowadays on Android. We used to just launch a `MediaStore.Audio.Media.RECORD_SOUND_ACTION` intent, and this worked pretty well on older Android versions since a 'Sound Recorder' app was included by default which handled this intent. Recent Android versions stopped including this app and most apps that I tried from the Play Store don't handle this intent.
On the other hand, Google has this doc (<http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/media/audio-capture.html>) on Audio Capturing but implementing this has the drawback that it will require having permission to access the device's microphone. Perhaps it's the only way now.

attachments.title: Audio Capture | Android Developers
attachments.text: The Android multimedia framework includes support for capturing and encoding a variety of common audio formats, so that you can easily integrate audio into your applications. You can record audio using the MediaRecorder APIs if supported by the device…
